description:
Leishmania panamensis is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the genus Leishmania, which is responsible for causing the disease known as cutaneous leishmaniasis. This species was originally isolated from a human patient in Colombia in 1981 and was given the designation MHOM/COL/81/L13.

Leishmania panamensis is a digenetic parasite, meaning it has two distinct life stages: the promastigote form, which lives and multiplies in the gut of sand flies (the vector), and the amastigote form, which resides and replicates within the macrophages of the human host.

Genetically, Leishmania panamensis is classified within the Viannia subgenus of the Leishmania genus and is closely related to other species that cause cutaneous leishmaniasis in Central and South America, such as Leishmania braziliensis and Leishmania guyanensis.

This species is known to cause a localized form of cutaneous leishmaniasis, characterized by the development of one or more skin lesions at the site of the sand fly bite. The clinical manifestations can range from self-healing ulcers to more severe and complicated forms of the disease.

Understanding the biology and epidemiology of Leishmania panamensis is crucial for the development of effective control strategies and the improvement of diagnostic and treatment methods for cutaneous leishmaniasis in the regions where this parasite is endemic.
